The Celebration of Satire

As you'd expect Sacha Baron Cohen made the biggest of entrances to this years Cannes Film Festival

Faust

There are an endless number of characters in film, theatre and literature who are variations of Faust, the virtuous man who sold his soul to the devil

Albert Nobbs

If you're a Downton fan, then step aside Maggie old girl and let through this brilliantly cast film which also takes a close look at the 'downstairs'

The Cannes Film Festival - What's the point?

It is that time of year again when the great and the good of the international media descend upon the South of France for the World's most prestigious film festival

The Dictator

One would expect the bluster, brazenness and unreserved bulldozing of political correctness to be Sascha Baron Cohen's latest attempt in providing offensive humour

Girls in the Ring

Women are to compete in Olympic boxing for the first time. Sophie Rose Walker investigates why Yorkshire is leading the way in getting girls into boxing (Thumbnail credit Caption: Kimberley Brown, Hull Saints ABC, Hull, East Yorkshire. Copyright Lee Karen Stow @ Girls in the Ring)

Creative Director of iMove, Tessa Gordziejko speaks to Tom Witherow about Yorkshire's Cultural Olympiad

You can't help but feel like Mary Lennox from Burnett's The Secret Garden here (Thumbnail credit York Sculpture Park)

Pygmalion

An uplifting performance punctuated with comedy, Pygmalion exposes the obvious tensions and unexpected similarities between classes in the late 19th century.

Birmingham Royal Ballet at York Theatre Royal

The Birmingham Royal Ballet provided a night of seamless dancing, colourful music and exceptionally taught buttocks.

The Met Ball

If there was one Couture event to get excited about, this would be it (Thumbnail credit Carey Mulligan Met 2012)

Fourth Movement

The small details of set changes and other technical aspects could be improved. Nevertheless, Fourth Movement explored the issues of mental illness and marital breakdown with perceptive insight and talent from its actors

The Price of Talent

By James Bithell

Britain's Got Talent draws audiences in the tens of millions, but at what cost? Bella Foxwell investigates (Thumbnail credit The BGT Parade)

El Perro Andaluz

Highly accomplished contemporary music, but not fun to listen to

Headhunters

An adaptation from a novel by the up-and-coming Norweigan crime author Jo Nesbo, Headhunters is just the latest entry in the recent explosion of 'Nordic Noir'

York: Five days below the Poverty Line

Reliving the lives of billions: Tom Witherow talks to two people at York who, this week, are living off just a PS1 a day

Out of my head: Paul Merton

Paul Merton's new tour was disappointing; both in the comedian's lack of convincing punchlines, and in his over-reliance on his fellow performers.

Review: URY O'Sullivan and Mawn

A few teething problems aside, O'Sullivan and Mawn's new radio show is genuinely brilliant.

Adam 'MCA' Yauch: 1964-2012

Beastie Boys' Adam Yauch was simply 'irreplaceable', his contributions to music, film and human rights are staggering (as you can see from the length of this obituary) and he is a man whom will never be forgotten (Thumbnail credit Photo Credit: Mick Hutson/Redferns)

Blue/Orange

Blue/Orange takes you deeper in to the human mind with every second.

Deathwatch

Jean Genet's one act play about three prisoners, Green Eyes, Lefranc and Maurice.
